feed.title: Combined summary - Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks

entry.title: Combined summary - Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
entry.summary:
The recent discussions within the Bitcoin development community have shed light on serious vulnerabilities in the Wasabi & GingerWallet, as well as the CoinJoin protocols utilized by both wallets and the Samourai wallet. These vulnerabilities are not new discoveries but rather stem from fundamental issues inherent in the designs of these protocols, highlighting a significant trust problem between users and coordinators. The critique particularly focuses on the coordinators' behavior, which ranges from rent-seeking to incompetence, exacerbating the privacy risks. This skepticism is partly due to the abandonment of WabiSabi, a protocol meant for Wasabi Wallet and GingerWallet, over concerns regarding its effectiveness.
For Whirlpool, one identified vulnerability involves the manipulation of blind signing keys. This manipulation allows a server to link transaction outputs back to their inputs by assigning unique RSA keys to each input during the confirmation phase, thus compromising the privacy promised by the protocol. On the other hand, WabiSabi faces challenges with key consistency. It operates on the basis that clients independently register Bitcoin UTXOs, with requests including BIP-322 ownership proofs tied to specific round IDs. The potential for issuing inconsistent round IDs opens up avenues for deanonymization through partitioning.
Despite efforts to address these vulnerabilities, the core problems persist, mainly due to ineffective verification and control over the public keys used in proof verifications. Other contributing factors to the risk of deanonymization include poor coin selection practices, timing of input registrations, and inadequate management of Tor circuits. The protocol's reliance on JSON and HTTP could also introduce variability in data serialization, further endangering user privacy.
Moreover, the economic incentives built into the system, such as coordination fees and the anonymous credential mechanism, have failed to prevent fund thefts, indicating a significant oversight in balancing privacy protection with financial security for users. This ongoing debate underscores the critical balance between advancing privacy-enhancing technologies and maintaining high standards of security and trust among users. The dialogue reflects the broader challenges faced by the cryptocurrency community in developing protocols that adequately protect user privacy while preventing exploitation.
